newsitem.title: USA: U.S. travelers told to prepare for BA strike.
newsitem.headline: U.S. travelers told to prepare for BA strike.

text.p: U.S. travelers bound for London on British Airways were told by travel agents on Monday to make contingency plans in case airline cabin crew go on strike on Wednesday as expected.
American Society of Travel Agents president and chief executive officer Mike Spinelli said the planned 72-hour strike meant most alternative flights were already fully booked.

"Since a strike appears imminent, one of the best options for those travelers already booked an a British Airways flight between July 9 and July 12 is to work with their travel agents in booking refundable tickets on alternative carriers," Spinelli said.
He also advised transatlantic fliers with connections to allow enough time for delays and to try avoid being booked on the last flight of the day.
Airlines are not legally required to provide compensation or overnight accommodations if flights are delayed or even canceled, he said.
BA said it had prepared for a strike and had launched contingency plans to continue to operate up to 80 percent of its flights.
Worst-affected flights will be BA intercontinental services from London's Heathrow and Gatwick airports and its European services out of Heathrow, BA said.
